definition: to make trouble out of nothing
not to have/no/none/not/to lack/un-/-less
matter/thing/item/work/affair/CL:件[jian4],樁|桩[zhuang1],回[hui2]
to be born/to give birth/life/to grow/raw/uncooked/student
abbr. for 非洲[Fei1 zhou1], Africa
to not be/not/wrong/incorrect/non-/un-/in-/to reproach or blame/(colloquial) to insist on/simply must

sentences.english: The moral to this story is, "Don't make much ado about nothing."
sentences.chinese: 这个故事的道德是，“不要无事生非。”

sentences.english: "Much Ado About Nothing" is a good example of a Shakespearian comedy.
sentences.chinese: 《无事生非》是莎士比亚喜剧的一个范例。

sentences.english: The whole controversy is far too much ado about absolutely nothing.
sentences.chinese: 整个争议完全是无事生非。

definition: to incite a quarrel (idiom); to sow discord between people/to tell tales/to make mischief
to start rumours and create trouble
to incite a quarrel (idiom); to sow discord between people/to tell tales/to make mischief
to look for employment/to pick a quarrel
to sow dissension (idiom); to drive a wedge between
to stir up trouble
variant of 惹是生非[re3 shi4 sheng1 fei1]
to pester endlessly (idiom)/an annoying troublemaker
to use the current topic to put over one's own ideas/to use sth as a pretext to make a fuss
to take advantage of one's position to bully people (idiom)/to kick people around
to pick fault with/to spot the differences/to nitpick/to pick a quarrel/to find complaint with
meddling in other people's business
lit. chasing the wind and clutching at shadows (idiom); fig. groundless accusations/to act on hearsay evidence
lit. to point at the mulberry tree and curse the locust tree/fig. to scold sb indirectly/to make oblique accusations (idiom)
to pick a quarrel/to start a fight
to incite/to stir up/to instigate
